text: Nina Dobrev shines in this movie as a comedic actress and honestly, it was so much fun to watch her tackle this genre. People have mentioned a lack of chemistry between the leads where as I felt there was undeniable comparability. While all in all, his actions were deplorable at the beginning, I think just like Hot Frosty, there’s a level of disbelief that has to be suspended as we enjoy the Christmas lightheartedness of it all. Realistically, if this was trying to pass for anything but a sweet Netflix Christmas film, its themes are worthy of criticism. He catfishes her? Forces a fake proposal? Lies to his family only to be greeted with sympathy when she tells the truth? She’s the one who apologises to him by the end for simply trying to get to know the other guy he pretended he was, and then she’s the problem for having been honest? Look it’s all the stuff of nightmares - if this film had been anything other than a lighthearted Christmas movie. And I think it speaks to both actors, and the writers credit, that you do end up smiles beaming for the pair of them by the end anyway. So I say, let it be Christmas and have some fun with this film. It’s geuinely funny, not Netflix try hard funny. It’s warm, well-filmed, Christmasy, and honestly a stand out for Nina. Anyone who knows her from vampire diaries would know her range is impeccable and she deserves way bigger credit in the acting world than she gets - but she really is a likeable lead who manages to be equal parts funny and sympathetic due to her chaotic romantic clumsiness. Maybe I’m basic that this is actualy one of my favourite modern Christmas movies, but I think it manages to strike such a perfect tone with what is essentially a touch concept to tackle in a way that didn’t borderline offend victims of catfishing. I must admit I personally felt them being good friends would have been a more … appropriate ending. As I felt Natalie suddenly had to - for narrative reasons - be painted as much a fake as Josh with how she pretended her interests for Tag’s sake, and her past dating life was used as a criticism of how she views men, which felt all too convenient when she is at her core a victim of catfishing. But I loved how Josh wasn’t some loser who was socially awkward or geeky, he was intelligent, charming, actually confident to a degree in his wit, and I think he was a one-off example of how societal expectations have wrecked the confidence of young men - and he himself was a rare case where he was all in all an attractive person , just not conventionally, which led him to catfish, so look, it’s not a perfect trope, but for Christmas, pour a glass of wine, enjoy their talents and humour, and love it, actually.

The plot was great and the movie was well done, but there was so little chemistry between the main characters, and the male lead was so unattractive, that it seemed unbelievable to me. The movie settled for just one non-passionate kiss, which was a relief.

I watch this one every Christmas and it never gets old. It is very easy to watch and enjoy, and it fits perfectly into that spot where you are either easing into the Christmas season or trying to get reminded of it again.

The comedy hits the right balance. Nothing is overdone and nothing feels undercooked. It is simple, fun, and comfortable. The kind of holiday movie you can put on without thinking too hard and still walk away smiling.

I give it an 8 out of 10 because I like it. Plain and simple.
Another good Christmas romantic comedy. And although the couple doesn’t match aesthetically, I felt a real chemistry between them — and that makes all the difference. It’s worth checking out.

Love Hard captures the messy beauty of modern romance — where screens connect hearts as easily as they disguise lies. Natalie, a hopeful writer tired of failed relationships, believes she’s finally found “the one” in Josh, only to discover she’s been catfished. What begins as deception slowly transforms into an unexpected journey of honesty and vulnerability. Despite its lighthearted tone and festive charm, the film gently reminds us that love isn’t about perfection or appearances, but the courage to be real — because sometimes, the truest connection comes from the heart, not the picture.

"Love Hard" is the kind of Christmas rom-com that gets under your skin in the best way possible. It's a delightful blend of humor, romance, and a bit of self-aware wit that makes it stand out in the crowded holiday movie landscape. I found the plot engaging, and sweet enough heart to make watch it beginning to end.

Jimmy O. Yang and Nina Dobrev bring their characters to life with fantastic chemistry and charm. Yang’s performance as the endearing underdog and Dobrev’s role as the relatable, albeit sometimes insufferable, protagonist kept me hooked from start to finish. Their dynamic is both touching and hilarious, making the inevitable romance feel both earned and authentic.

The movie also cleverly nods to holiday classics and rom-com tropes, all while maintaining a fresh and modern vibe. From the hilarious Christmas caroling scene to the debate over whether "Die Hard" is a Christmas movie, it’s filled with moments resonated with me as a movie fan.

The soundtrack is perfectly chosen, enhancing the movie’s warm and cozy feel, and the writing balances the comedic and heartfelt moments with finesse.

However, it's not without its clichés – there are sassy best friends, stern bosses, and wacky grandparents. But these elements are handled with such a light touch that they feel more like affectionate tributes than tired tropes. The film's ability to poke fun at itself while delivering a genuinely touching love story is what makes it special.

Despite a few predictable moments, "Love Hard" manages to be endearing and entertaining, a perfect pick for a cozy night in. Whether you're a die-hard rom-com fan or just looking for a feel-good Christmas movie, "Love Hard" is a delightful treat that’s well worth your time.

Dating isn’t easy but online dating is much harder Nina Dobrev plays Natalie, a woman who’s had nothing but bad luck when it comes to dating and relationships with men At the moment she’s turned her messy love life into a successful career writing about how difficult love is Her latest possible match on an app is a guy named Josh She decides to take a risk and meet this man of her dreams all the way in Lake Placid, NY Imagine her surprise when she finds out Josh isn’t real and she’s been cat fished by a guy named Josh who’s really shut in, closed off, and has no confidence Yet in another surprise twist Natalie finds the man who looks like the profile Josh created and now she needs this fake Josh’a help to win his affection The film is bright, colorful, cheerful, very funny, and Dobrev and Yang are a dime a dozen together A lovely soundtrack to go with as well When it comes to love or dating we have to show the real us, we can show our strengths and passions, authentic ness is better than pretending, hiding behind a computer screen/phone doesn’t allow us to really be ourselves, you’re still you despite the insecurities, slight exaggerations are okay but it can lead to disappointment and heartbreak, love has to be honest not perfect It’s not your typical Christmas rom com as its way more foul mouthed It’s also produced by McG of all things and the two leads don’t really have their romance that focused on 100% but director Hernan Jimenez does a pretty solid job with this one constructing its own charm It shows that even two people that aren’t perfect can make their own imperfections work, instead of finding our happy ending we can find our happy beginnings
